Ni/Al-MCM-41(x) catalysts were synthesized and tested in the hydrodeoxygenation of anisole as a model compound of bio-oil. Prepared catalysts behave as bifunctional metal-acid catalysts combining the metal function of the reduced Ni nanoparticles with the acid function of the Al-MCM-41 supports. Nickel loading in the catalysts was maintained constant (5 wt%), while Al content in the supports was varied (Si/Al molar ratios x = 120, 90, 60 and 30). The Ni/Al-MCM-41(x) catalysts showed significantly higher hydrodeoxygenation activities than the reference Ni/Al2O3 and the Ni/MCM-41 catalyst without Al. In addition, they showed high selectivity towards the formation of the deoxygenated products, with more than 96% selectivity to cyclohexane. The best activity and selectivity results were obtained with the Ni/Al-MCM-41(90) catalyst. This result was attributed to an optimum balance of metal and acid sites, both of which participate in different steps of anisole hydrodeoxygenation and generate a synergistic effect. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Bifunctional catalysts Nickel Al-MCM-41 Anisole Data Availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Nowadays, the global demand for fossil fuels impacts directly on the petroleum reserves and increases CO2 emissions. Consequently, there is a social, political, and environmental interest in the development of alternative energy sources, which must be sustainable, efficient, and economically competent to substitute fossil fuels [1]. In this sense, biofuels are an alternative to be employed in conventional transport. Second-generation biofuels are the most promising because they are produced from non-edible low-cost lignocellulosic biomass, such as forest and agricultural waste, fast-growing trees, etc., and do not compete with food production [2]. There are different techniques to generate biofuels from lignocellulosic biomass, where fast pyrolysis is the most efficient. In this case, biomass is transformed to bio-oil by thermal decomposition at mild conditions (450–600 °C) with low residence time (1–2 s) in the absence of oxygen [3,4]. Bio-oil is a viscous liquid composed by a mixture of several compounds that include mainly aromatics with methoxy- and hydroxy- substituents [5]. High oxygen content in the obtained bio-oil (ca. 40 wt%) [6] makes it corrosive and with lower heating value in comparison with conventional fuels. Therefore, an upgrading process is required to reduce the oxygen content in bio-oil, such as catalytic hydrotreatment (HDT) [7]. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is one of the HDT processes aimed especially at reducing oxygen content. It can be used to produce renewable fuels with similar properties to diesel or gasoline [8,9]. Conventional sulfided NiMo and CoMo catalysts can be used for HDO. However, they require a sulfur source to avoid the deactivation and, generally, they can contaminate the final products with sulfur [10–12]. Among other catalysts, supported noble metals (Rh, Pd, or Pt) have been widely studied for HDO; nevertheless, their large-scale application is non-viable because of a high cost [5,13]. On the other side, supported Ni catalysts are characterized by being non-expensive and able to carry out hydrogenation and hydrodeoxygenation reactions [4]. Different supports have been tested for these applications of Ni catalysts, e.g., silica, alumina [5], alumina-silica [14], other mixed oxides or mesoporous silica-based materials, such as SBA-15 and MCM-41 [15–17], which can be modified by introducing heteroatoms (Al, Ti, etc.) in their structure, to generate acid sites [18,19]. It is known that there is a synergistic relationship between the metal active phase and the acidity of the support, which improves the HDO performance of the catalysts. HDO generally occurs through different reaction routes, namely, i) direct deoxygenation (DDO), consisting in the hydrogenolysis of the C–O bond, and ii) the hydrogenation-deoxygenation route. In that way, supported Ni particles allow the hydrogenation reactions, while acid sites can promote the C–O bond cleavage through dehydration or acid cracking [4,5,7]. Particularly, MCM-41 is a mesostructured two-dimensional material with a high specific surface area (ca. 1000 m2/g), a pore diameter of 2–4 nm, a pore volume of ca. 1 cm3/g and excellent thermal and chemical stability [20,21]. MCM-41 and Al-MCM-41 materials have been widely used as supports or catalysts for different catalytic reactions [22–29]. However, there are just a few studies involving Al-MCM-41 as a Ni support for HDO. Recently, Nugraha et al. [30] studied deoxygenation of Reutealis trisperma oil over Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts at atmospheric pressure and under H2-free conditions. They found that NiO supported on Al-MCM-41 (up to 10 wt% loading) improved the Lewis acidity and enhanced the catalyst’s activity and selectivity toward hydrocarbons within the diesel range (C11-C18). Impregnation with 10 wt% of NiO on Al-MCM-41 also reduced the products from the cracking reaction, enhancing the yields of green diesel. Tran et al. [31,32] tested Ni/Al-MCM-41 (10 wt% of Ni) in vapor-phase hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol under atmospheric hydrogen pressure at different temperatures (300, 350, and 400 °C). Even though the catalyst showed a good conversion of guaiacol to aromatics, high temperatures were required, which increased the selectivity to gas-phase compounds. A comparison of Ni and Co catalysts supported on Al-MCM-41 in guaiacol HDO [32] revealed that the Ni catalyst showed a ring opening activity, while Co favored the deoxygenation activity. Results showed the bifunctional character of the Co/Al-MCM-41 catalyst which conducted the HDO of guaiacol by a combination of acidic and metallic functions. The acidic sites of the Al-MCM-41 support catalyzed the demethylation and transalkylation reactions, while metallic Co catalyzed the deoxygenation through hydrogenolysis of Caromatic-OR bond. On the other hand, Taghvaei et al. [33] tested Ni supported on Al-MCM-41 with different Si/Al molar ratios (10, 20, 40, and 60) in the HDO of anisole at atmospheric hydrogen pressure. All the catalysts showed high activity and selectivity under selected reaction conditions being phenol and benzene the main reaction products. Saturated products were not observed, due to the low hydrogen pressure. It was also shown that both Ni and Al are important for high catalytic activity. The catalyst´s acidity contributed to the hydrogenolysis of anisole and transalkylation reaction, whereas metallic Ni sites were able to contribute to further hydrodeoxygenation of the intermediate compounds. All the above-mentioned studies on the use of Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts in HDO were performed at atmospheric hydrogen pressure and pointed out to a bifunctional character of these catalytic systems. Herein, we report results on the use of Ni catalysts supported on mesoporous Al-modified MCM-41 with different Si/Al molar ratios (from 30 to 120) in the HDO of anisole at 300 oC and high H2 pressure (4.8 MPa). In these reaction conditions, reaction product distributions were completely different from those reported previously. The supports and catalysts were characterized by different techniques in order to elucidate the role of the acidic and metallic active sites on the activity and selectivity of the synthesized catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of supports and catalysts 2.1.1 Chemicals Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, ≥ 97%), fumed silica (particle size 0.2–0.3 µm), tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH, 20% wt. in H2O,), aluminum chloride (AlCl3, 99%), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2· 6 H2O, 99%,), anisole (99%), and hexadecane (99%) were purchased from Merck. Sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 95–98%) was purchased from J. K. Baker. Deionized water was used to prepare all solutions. 2.1.2 Synthesis of MCM-41 support The MCM-41 support was synthesized according to Méndez et al. [34]. In a conventional synthesis, a sodium silicate solution (Na2SiO3) was prepared by diluting 16 g of NaOH in 80 mL of deionized water, followed by the addition of 12 g of fumed silica. The suspension was heated at 70 °C to obtain a homogeneous solution, and then the mixture was cold down to room temperature, maintaining magnetic stirring (SOL-1). The second solution (SOL-2) is an aqueous micellar mixture of 5.9 g of TEAOH in 150 mL of deionized water, followed by the addition of 18.2 g of CTMAB under magnetic stirring. The SOL-1 was added dropwise to SOL-2, the pH was adjusted to 9 with a 10 M H2SO4 solution, and it was maintained under magnetic stirring for 2 h. The resulting mixture was matured at 104 °C for 24 h without stirring in a 1 L stainless steel autoclave. Subsequently, the obtained solid was filtered, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and dried for 24 h at room temperature. Finally, it was calcined at 550 °C in a static air atmosphere for 8 h (0.8 °C/min ramp). This support was labeled as MCM-41. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Al-MCM-41 supports To obtain Al-containing MCM-41 supports with desired Si/Al molar ratios, a third solution (SOL-3) was prepared by dissolving a corresponding amount of AlCl3 in 20 mL of deionized water. AlCl3 amounts used were 0.2241, 0.2983, 0.4483, and 0.8967 g for Si/Al molar ratios of 120, 90, 60 and 30, respectively). This solution was added dropwise to SOL-2 before the SOL-1 addition. Subsequently, the stirring, maturation, filtration, washing, drying, and calcination processes were realized as mentioned in the previous section. The Al-containing supports were labeled as AMx (AM120, AM90, AM60, and AM30 for Si/Al molar ratios (x) of 120, 90, 60, and 30, respectively). 2.1.4 Preparation of Ni catalysts The catalysts with a theoretical nickel loading of 5 wt% were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method, using an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O as a precursor. After impregnation, the catalysts were dried at room temperature for 24 h, then dried at 100 °C for 12 h (0.8 °C/min ramp), and finally calcined at 500 °C in a static air atmosphere for 2 h (3 °C/min ramp). The prepared catalysts were labeled as NiMCM, employing the MCM-41 support, and NAMx, using AMx supports with Si/Al molar ratios x = 120, 90, 60, and 30. 2.2 Characterization of supports and catalysts 2.2.1 Nitrogen physisorption The textural properties of supports and catalysts were determined on a Micromeritics 3FLEX automatic analyzer at liquid N2 temperature (−197.5 °C). Previously, the samples were degassed in a N2 flow at 270 °C for 12 h. The specific surface areas (SBET) were calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, the total pore volume (VP) was determined by the N2 adsorption at a relative pressure of 0.99, and pore diameter was determined from the adsorption isotherms by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. 2.2.2 X-ray diffraction Small-angle X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained at room temperature on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using small divergence and scattering slits of 0.05°, using CuKα radiation of λ = 1.5406 Å in the range of 0.6–10° (2θ). The wide-angle X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Siemens D5000 diffractometer with a goniometer speed of 1° (2θ)/min, in the range of 3–80° (2θ). The crystalline phases observed in the diffraction patterns were identified with the Powder Diffraction File (PDF) card number of the Joint Committee of Powder Diffraction Standards-International Center of Diffraction Data (JCPDS-ICDD) library. 2.2.3 UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of the supports and catalysts were recorded in the wavelength range of 200–800 nm on a Varian Cary 100 Conc. spectrophotometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance attachment. The reference material was polytetrafluoroethylene. 2.2.4 Elemental analysis Chemical composition of supports and catalysts was determined by Scanning Electron Microscopy coupled to an Energy-Dispersive X-ray analyzer (SEM-EDX) using a JEOL 5900 LV microscope with an OXFORD ISIS microanalyzer. 2.2.5 High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) The morphological characteristics of the reduced catalysts were obtained by HRTEM using a JEOL 2010 microscope (resolving power 1.9 Å at 200 kV). The solids were ultrasonically dispersed in heptane and the suspension was collected on a carbon coated grids. HRTEM pictures were taken from different parts of the same sample disperse on the microscope grid. For each catalyst, about 300 particles of the reduced nickel were counted to obtain a frequency histogram of the Ni particle size. 2.2.6 Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) Both H2-TPR and NH3-TPD analyses were performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 automatic analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Prior to H2-TPR experiments, the catalysts were pretreated at 500 °C for 2 h and cooled down to room temperature in an Ar stream. The temperature-programmed reduction of the catalysts was carried out from 25° to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, under a stream of H2/Ar mixture (10:90 molar ratio, 50 mL/min flow). The consumption of H2 at different temperatures was recorded. For the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia, the samples were pretreated in situ at 500 °C for 30 min in a He flow, in order to remove water and other contaminants. Then the samples were cooled to 120 °C and contacted with a He/NH3 mixture (90/10 mol/mol, 20 mL/min flow) for 30 min. The desorption step was performed with a pure He stream (50 mL/min flow) from 120 °C to 500 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, keeping the final temperature until the trace reached the baseline. 2.3 Catalytic activity tests Prior to the catalytic activity tests in HDO of anisole, the catalysts were activated by an ex situ reduction process in a U-s haped glass flow reactor at 400 °C for 4 h, under a stream of H2/Ar (70:30 molar ratio) at atmospheric pressure. The HDO reactions were performed in a 300 mL stainless-steel batch reactor (Parr) equipped with a thermocouple, a mechanical stirrer, a pressure sensor, a gas entrainment impeller and a system for controlling temperature, stirring rate, and pressure. For each experiment, 50 mL of a 5 wt% solution of anisole in hexadecane and 0.1 g of the reduced Ni catalyst were loaded into the reactor. In order to prevent re-oxidation, the reduced catalyst was transferred into the reactor in Ar atmosphere. The sealed reactor was purged with pure N2 and H2 at room temperature to evacuate air, then pressurized with H2 to 3.3 MPa and heated to the reaction temperature. At the reaction temperature, the pressure increased to 4.8 MPa, and time and stirring (500 rpm) were initiated. The reactions were performed at 280 °C for 6 h. To monitor the reaction progress, liquid samples of the reaction mixture (∼0.5 mL) were collected from the reactor using a custom-made sampling system. The samples were taken every 15 min in the first hour, 30 min in the second hour, and finally, every hour until the reaction finished. The samples were analyzed in an Agilent 6890 gas chromatograph equipped with an FID detector and non-polar methyl siloxane HP-1 capillary column (50 mm × 0.32 mm inner diameter and 0.52 µm film thickness). The products were identified by mass spectroscopy on an Agilent 7890 A GC system equipped with a 5975 C MS detector. The concentrations of compounds in the mixture were calculated by the internal normalization method. For each compound in the mixture, its concentration C i is proportional to the area of its chromatographic peak multiplied to the corresponding sensitivity factor. Sensitivity factors were determined for anisole and the reaction products detected in the mixture by the external calibration procedure using corresponding neat reagents. The catalytic activity was determined by measuring the anisole concentration at different reaction times. The conversion of anisole (X AN ) was calculated by Eq. 1. (1) X AN = C AN 0 − C AN C AN 0 × 100 % Where C AN0 is the initial anisole concentration (mol L-1) and C AN is the concentration of anisole (mol L-1) at time t (h). Initial reaction rates (r 0 ) were determined as the slopes of the anisole conversion curves at initial reaction time. The reaction rate constants were calculated assuming that anisole HDO reactions are of pseudo-first order using Eq. 2, where k is the pseudo-first order reaction constant expressed in (h−1), X AN is fractional anisole conversion and t the reaction time (h). Data from the first hour reaction time were used for the k calculations (see Fig. S3, Supporting information). Fitting parameters of the linear plots shown in Fig. S3 (b) are shown in Table S1 . (2) − ln 1 − X AN = kt The selectivity to cyclohexane (S CHA ) was calculated by Eq. 3. (3) S CHA = C CHA ∑ C products × 100 % Where C i is the concentration of the product i (mol L-1) at time t. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supports and calcined catalysts 3.1.1 SEM-EDX characterization SEM-EDX results showed that the chemical compositions of AMx supports (Si/Al molar ratio, Table 1) were close to the theoretically expected ones. Thus, Al-containing MCM-41 supports with the Si/Al molar ratios equal to 121, 85, 56 and 30 were successfully synthesized, which corresponds well to the expected ratios in AM120, AM90, AM60 and AM30 materials. The chemical compositions of the Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts were also determined by SEM-EDX. In all the cases, the real metal loadings were very close to the theoretical one (5 wt% of Ni, Table 2). Elemental mapping images of Al and Ni are shown in Fig. 1. It was observed that both Al and Ni species showed a good dispersion and a homogeneous distribution in all calcined Ni catalysts. As expected, Al loading in the catalysts increases with decreasing Si/Al molar ratio in the corresponding supports. 3.1.2 N2 physisorption The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the supports and catalysts are shown in Fig. 2(a and b, respectively). All the supports exhibit type IV isotherms corresponding to mesoporous materials with a notorious increase in the adsorbed volume at relative pressures (P/P0) between 0.25 and 0.35. This increase corresponds to the capillary condensation of liquid nitrogen in the mesopores of (Al)-MCM-41 supports, as reported by Lensveld et al. [35]. On the other hand, the absence of a hysteresis loop in this relative pressure interval points out to a very regular uniform pore size in the synthesized supports. Addition of aluminum to the MCM-41 silica support produced a decrease in the amount of adsorbed nitrogen, as well as the appearance of the type H3 hysteresis at relative pressures 0.45–1.0. This hysteresis can be ascribed to free spaces between the support’s particles and indicates that the addition of Al produced some changes in the particles size and shape. The physisorption isotherms of the Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts (Fig. 2b) have the same shape as those of the respective supports indicating that the characteristic mesoporous structure of the supports was maintained after the impregnation of nickel nitrate precursor and calcination. Both (Al)-MCM-41 supports and Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts showed very narrow pore size distributions centered at 26 Å (Fig. 2, c and d). The only difference is that in the catalysts, pore volume was smaller than that in the corresponding supports. To compare quantitatively the textural characteristics of materials, Tables 1 and 2 show the textural properties of the supports and catalysts, respectively. Pure silica MCM-41 showed the highest specific surface area (1079 m2/g), which decreased with aluminum incorporation and increasing in its loading, to 815, 816, 785, and 669 m2/g, for AM120, AM90, AM60, and AM30, respectively (Table 1). Similar trends were also observed for the total pore volume (VP) of the supports. The surface area and the total pore volume of the (Al)-MCM-41 supports significantly decreased after the addition of nickel (Table 2). The above decrease in the SBET and VP values was larger for the pure silica MCM-41 support (23% and 26%, respectively), while it was less notorious for the Al-containing samples, suggesting that Al incorporation to the MCM-41 supports improved the dispersion of Ni oxide species in the catalysts. A strong decrease in the specific textural characteristics of the MCM-41 after the addition of nickel may be due to pore obstruction by the agglomerated NiO particles. 3.1.3 X-ray diffraction Fig. 3 shows small-angle diffractograms (2θ = 0.6–10°) of the supports and catalysts. MCM-41 exhibits the typical peaks of the hexagonal arrangement of mesopores at 2.34, 4.09, and 4.72°(2θ), related to (1 0 0), (1 1 0), and (2 0 0) planes, respectively [36]. These signals are also presented in the patterns of Al-modified supports and catalysts, although they are slightly shifted to smaller 2θ degrees compared to the pure silica MCM-41, indicating an increase in the interplanar distances d 100 after the incorporation of aluminum. The above results demonstrate that the characteristic hexagonal pore structure of the MCM-41 was maintained after the incorporation of aluminum and nickel. Pore wall thickness (δ) of the supports and catalysts was calculated using the position of the main (1 0 0) reflection observed in small-angle XRD patterns and pore diameter (DP) found by N2 physisorption (Tables 1 and 2). For the MCM-41 and NiMCM materials, pore wall thickness was 1.7 nm, while the Al-containing supports and catalysts had a pore wall thickness between 2.1 and 2.3 nm. These results are in line with our previous observations [37], where the increment of the pore wall thickness was ascribed to the isomorphous substitution of Si atoms by larger Al atoms. The wide-angle X-ray diffraction patterns of supports and catalysts are shown in Fig. 4a and b, respectively. MCM-41 exhibits a wide peak at 15–40°(2θ), which is characteristic of amorphous silica. Other signals related to any crystalline phase of Al2O3 were not observed in the XRD patterns of the AMx supports, indicating a good dispersion of aluminum in the AMx materials. Calcined Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts, in addition to the wide peak of the amorphous (Al)-MCM-41 supports, presented the characteristic diffraction signals of cubic NiO crystalline phase at 37.34, 43.28, 62.86 and 75.39°(2θ), which correspond to its (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0) and (3 1 1) planes, respectively (Fig. 4b). The intensity of the NiO signals decreased with Al incorporation to the MCM-41 support. Thus, the lowest intensity wide NiO signals were observed for the NAM120 catalyst. The size of the NiO crystallites in this catalyst estimated with the Scherrer equation was 6.8 nm, while for the NiMCM reference it was near 14.8 nm. However, a further increase in the Al loading in the AMx supports to x = 90, 60 and 30, resulted in some increase of NiO crystallite size to 9–13 nm. This can be a result of two opposite effects: on the one side, a dispersion of NiO species should increase due to their interaction with Al species in the supports [37], but on the other side, the specific surface areas of the AMx supports decrease with increasing Al loading (Table 1). 3.1.4 Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of the calcined Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5. All catalysts exhibit the three characteristic bands of Ni2+ in octahedral coordination. The band at ∼200–350 nm is associated with ligand to metal charge transfer (LMTC) from the 2p orbitals of O2– to Ni2+, where the shoulder at ∼255 nm is related to NiO with a smaller particle size than that of the band at ∼290 nm. The signals at 430 and 750 nm are related to electronic transitions of the d–d orbitals of the Ni2+. In addition, the band gap energies of the NiO species in Al-modified catalysts were 3.71 ± 0.02 eV (Table 2), which is larger than that of the NiMCM reference (3.66 eV). These results also corroborate a better dispersion of NiO species in the catalysts supported on Al-containing MCM-41 supports [38], in line with observations made by N2 physisorption (changes in SBET and VP values of supports and catalysts) and XRD. 3.1.5 Temperature-programmed reduction H2-TPR characterization of calcined catalysts was performed to obtain information about reducibility of nickel oxide species in the prepared Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts. The acquired reduction profiles are shown in Fig. 6. The thermogram of the NiMCM catalyst shows the presence of only one well-defined reduction peak with the maximum at 394 oC. This signal can be attributed to the reduction of NiO species in weak interaction with the silica support [35]. On the other side, the reduction profiles of the NAMx catalysts exhibit two signals, indicating the presence of Ni oxide species of different characteristics [35]. The first peak of H2 consumption at 365–382 °C is related to the reduction of large NiO nanoparticles dispersed on the external surface of the Al-MCM-41 supports of different chemical compositions, previously detected by XRD. These particles are in low metal-support interaction, their reduction temperature is similar to that of bulk NiO [26] and almost does not depend on the support’s Si/Al ratio. The second reduction peak can be attributed to the reduction of dispersed NiO species located inside the hexagonal mesopores of the Al-MCM-41 supports. These species are reduced at higher temperatures (450–502 oC) due to a stronger metal-support interaction. The exact position of the second reduction signal is sensitive to the supports’ Si/Al ratio and their textural characteristics (SBET). In the case of NAM120, NAM90, and NAM60 catalysts, the second reduction peak was located at 475–502 oC and its intensity was larger than that of the first low-temperature reduction signal. This points out to an increase in the proportion of dispersed NiO species inside the mesopores of AM120, AM90 and AM60 supports. This result once again confirms an increase in NiO dispersion on the Al-containing MCM-41 supports. The reduction profile of the NAM30 catalyst showed a change in the proportion of NiO species located inside and outside the mesopore structure of Al-MCM-41 support. In this case, a larger amount of NiO species were observed on the external surface of the support’s particles compared to other Al-containing supports. Probably, this is due to the lowest surface area of the AM30 support (Table 1). The degrees of reduction of Ni2+ oxide species (α) in the different catalysts are shown in Table 2. NiMCM and NAM30 catalysts showed higher degrees of reduction (0.99 and 0.96, respectively) than other NAMx catalysts (α = 0.75 – 0.86). According to the estimated values of α, the proportion of reduced NiO species in the Ni catalysts supported on Al-containing MCM-41 supports increased in the order: NAM120 < NAM60 ≈ NAM90 < NAM30. This order is well in line with the increase in the aluminum loading in the supports, which indicates that the hydrogen consumption increases when the Si/Al molar ratio decreases. 3.1.6 Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia Acidity of the synthesized Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts was characterized by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD). This method allows determining the amount and the strength of acid sites in solid samples without distinguishing the acid sites’ nature (Brønsted or Lewis). The obtained NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts ( Fig. 7) were deconvoluted into three or four signals as a function of the desorption temperature (see Fig. S1, Supporting information). Thus, the low-temperature deconvolution peak (maximum between 120 and 200 °C) was assigned to weak acid sites; the medium-temperature wide signal with the maximum located between 250 and 300 °C was assigned to medium-strength acid sites, and the signals with maxima between 400 and 500 °C to strong acid sites. Results of the quantification of acid sites of different strengths in the catalysts are shown in Table 3. NiMCM exhibits predominantly weak and medium acid sites, with the lowest total amount of acid sites among all synthesized catalysts. Addition of Al to the MCM-41 support and increase in its loading resulted in a progressive increase in the total amount of acid sites in the catalysts, as well as in their surface density. According to the total acidity (calculated per gram or m2), the catalysts can be ordered as NiMCM < < NAM120 < NAM90 < NAM60 < NAM30. This is in line with previous publication [39]. From the above results it can be concluded that the modification of MCM-41 materials by the isomorphous substitution of Si by Al atoms, as expected, improved the acidic properties of the prepared Ni catalysts. However, a more detailed analysis of the behavior of acid sites of different strengths shows that the amounts of weak and medium-strength acid sites increase in line with Al content in the supports. On the other hand, the amount of strong acid sites shows a different behavior. Thus, the NAM90 and NAM30 catalysts show higher amounts of strong acid sites than other catalysts. This is probably related to two opposite effects. The first one is an increment of the thickness (δ) of the Al-MCM-41 walls with increasing Al loading (from 2.1 to 2.3 nm) and a decrease in the specific surface area, SBET (Tables 1 and 2). Strong acid sites are generally related to the presence of tetrahedral framework Al species (Al(Td)) located on the pore wall surface, and as a result only ∼10–15% of the present aluminum gives rise to the acid sites [40]. In thicker walls, the relative proportion of tetrahedral Al species inaccessible to the interaction with ammonia molecules increases with increasing contents of aluminum, and, thus, the amount of strong acid sites decreases. On the other hand, a decrease in the Si/Al ratio could produce an increase in the surface density of Al(Td) species and, therefore, an increase in the acidity. Amount and strength of acid sites in the Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts is expected to affect their performance in the HDO of anisole. 3.2 Characterization of reduced catalysts 3.2.1 Powder XRD characterization Prior to the catalytic activity tests, the prepared nickel catalysts were reduced at 400 °C for 4 h. Fig. 8 shows X-ray diffraction patterns of reduced Ni catalysts supported on MCM-41 silica and Al-containing AM90 and AM30 materials. The XRD pattern of the reduced NiMCM catalyst showed the presence of only one crystalline phase. Thus, three reflections at 44.7°, 52.1° and 76.8° (2θ) correspond to the reduced metallic Ni0 crystals (JCPDS-ICDD card 01–071–4655). No signals corresponding to the presence of some remaining NiO crystalline phase were observed for this sample after reduction. This result points out to the complete transformation of nickel oxide species to the reduced metallic Ni, in line with previous report [23]. According to the H2-TPR observations (Fig. 6) the maximum of the reduction temperature of NiO species in the NiMCM catalyst was found at 394 oC, a temperature slightly lower than that used in the present work for the reduction of the calcined catalysts (400 oC, 4 h). The crystal size of the metallic Ni nanoparticles in the reduced NiMCM catalyst was estimated with the Scherrer equation using the (1 1 1) reflection of Ni0 giving a value around 14 nm. On the other hand, XRD diffraction patterns of the reduced NAM90 and NAM30 catalysts showed the presence of both NiO and Ni crystalline phases. In addition to the most intense (1 1 1) reflection of metallic Ni at 44.7o (2θ), three other detected signals at 37.2°, 43.3° and 62.8° (2θ) are due to the presence of the NiO crystalline phase (JCPDS-ICDD card 01–071–1179). The relative proportions of the Ni and NiO phases in the reduced NAM90 and NAM30 samples seem to be different. Such an incomplete reduction of NiO species deposited on Al-containing MCM-41 materials could be attributed to a stronger metal-support interaction as shown by H2-TPR results. For the reduced NAM90 and NAM30 catalysts, the most intense reflections of Ni and NiO phases were overlapped. Because of this, the crystal size of Ni and NiO nanoparticles was estimated after deconvolution of (2 0 0) reflection of NiO phase located at 43.3o (2θ) and (1 1 1) reflection of metallic Ni at 44.7o (2θ) (Fig. S2, Supporting information). The size of Ni0 nanoparticles was 10.1 nm for the NAM90 and 10.5 nm for the NAM30, respectively. Therefore, the obtained results indicate an increase in the dispersion of metallic Ni on Al-containing supports in comparison with the NiMCM sample. Regarding the NiO crystal size, it was 7.5 nm and 7.6 nm for NAM90 and NAM30, respectively. 3.2.2 HRTEM characterization The HRTEM micrographs of the reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 9. All materials exhibit the presence of nanoparticles as grey-black spots of different sizes. As shown by powder XRD of the reduced catalysts (Fig. 8), NiO species were completely reduced only in the NiMCM catalyst, while both Ni and NiO crystalline phases were coexisting in the NAM30 and NAM90 catalysts after reduction at 400 oC for 4 h. It is difficult to distinguish between Ni and NiO crystals in the HRTEM images shown in Fig. 9. The majority of the observed nanoparticles has the size larger than the pore channels of the (Al)-MCM-41 supports that points out to their location on the external surface of the mesoporous supports. Nevertheless, some very small Ni or NiO particles (ca. 2 nm) can also be observed inside the hexagonal mesopores (see white arrows indicating these particles). Therefore, the observations made by HRTEM confirm our previous conclusion based on the results from DRS and H2-TPR of calcined catalysts regarding coexistence of two types of nickel species in the catalysts: agglomerated species on the external surface and the dispersed ones inside the mesopores. Size distributions of reduced Ni or oxidized NiO nanoparticles are also shown in Fig. 9. The NiMCM catalyst has the widest particle size distribution with Ni particles between 2 and 34 nm size. The average value of Ni0 particle size in this catalyst is near 16 nm, which is the highest average size among all the studied catalysts. Catalysts supported on Al-containing MCM-41 materials, in general, show narrower size distributions (2–24 nm) with smaller average size of Ni0/NiO particles (between 10 and 12 nm). This result is in line with an increase in the dispersion of the NiO precursor in the calcined Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts compared to the NiMCM reference as it was detected by wide-angle XRD. Better dispersed NiO particles give rise to a smaller-size Ni particles in reduced catalysts. It should be mentioned that the size of the reduced Ni particles estimated by HRTEM is of the same order of magnitude as the size of NiO crystallites determined in the calcined catalysts by XRD using the Scherrer equation. Similar trends in the dispersion of NiO and Ni0 species were observed as a result of the addition of Al to the MCM-41 supports, namely, a better dispersion of both on Al-containing supports. It should be also mentioned that the ordered hexagonal mesopore structure of the (Al)-MCM-41 supports was maintained in all the catalysts after reduction treatment (see Fig. S3, supporting information). 3.3 Catalytic evaluation in HDO of anisole The catalytic activity of the reduced Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts was tested in the HDO of anisole upon the following reaction conditions: batch reactor, 280 °C, 4.8 MPa of H2 total pressure. A Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (5 wt% of Ni) was used as a reference for comparison purposes. Activities of the catalysts were compared based on the initial reaction rates of anisole consumption and pseudo-first order rate constants shown in Table 4. According to the initial reaction rates (r 0 ), the most active catalyst was NAM90, followed by NAM60, NAM30, NAM120, Ni/Al2O3 and, finally, the NiMCM without Al. Catalytic activity of the NAM90 catalyst in HDO was twice higher than that of the reference Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The reaction rate constants (k) were calculated using the pseudo-first order kinetic model and anisole conversions obtained with different catalysts at the first hour reaction time (Fig. S4 and Table S1, Supporting information). The values of the constants k and k’ (Table 4) confirmed the same order of activity of the catalysts: NAM90 > NAM60 > NAM30 > NAM120 ≫ Ni/Al2O3 > NiMCM, demonstrating that there is a significant enhancement in the catalytic activity when the support is modified with aluminum. Thus, anisole conversions obtained at 6 h reaction time with all Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts (NAMx) were of about 96–97% (Table 4), while the less active NiMCM and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts resulted only in 38.6% and 63.4% of conversion, respectively. For comparison purposes, the obtained catalytic activity results were compared with those previously published in the literature. Thus, in work [17], Ni catalysts (10 wt% Ni) supported on SBA-15 silica and protonated titanate nanotubes were tested in anisole HDO upon the same reaction conditions as in the present study. Obtained reaction rate constants were between 0.56 and 1.49 h-1, which is smaller than the activity (k, Table 4) shown by the NAM90 and NAM60 catalysts with only 5 wt% of Ni. On the other hand, Ni catalyst supported on USY zeolite showed a first-order rate constant equal to 1.86 × 10-4 s-1 (0.67 h-1) in liquid phase HDO of anisole at a reaction temperature of 200 oC and 750 psi (5.2 MPa) pressure [41]. NiCu-SiO2 catalysts with a metal content of 90% and different Ni/Cu ratios were investigated in HDO of anisole at 280 oC and 6 MPa pressure [42]. The monometallic Ni-SiO2 catalyst showed k = 0.224 min-1 gcat -1 (3.73 ×10-3 s-1 ×gcat -1), which is smaller than the corresponding value of 5.00 × 10-3 s-1×gcat -1 found in the present work for the most active NAM90 catalyst. From the above information, it can be concluded that the Ni catalysts developed in the present work show similar o slightly better activities in HDO of anisole than the above samples. A mass balance approximation for the reactants and products present in the liquid phase was made by the Gas Chromatography Liquid Phase Analysis (GCLPA, Table 4). Gaseous and heavy products (oligomerization products and carbonaceous solids precursors of coke deposits on the surface and in the mesopores of the prepared NAMx catalysts) have not been quantified. As shown in Table 4, GCLPA values varied between 58.3% and 67.3% without a clear trend related to the amount of Al incorporated in the AMx support. According to the obtained GCLPA results, the formation of some coke (ca. 10–20 wt%) can be expected in all the catalysts tested in the present work. This is in line with the recent publications [25,43], where the formation of 12.8–21.7 wt% of coke was observed in the HDO of guaiacol over Pd-Co and Pd-Fe catalysts supported on Al-MCM-41 (flow reactor, 400 oC, ambient pressure). Coke formation was also observed during the methanol dehydration reaction over Al-MCM-41 nanospheres at 300 oC [22]. In addition to the above-mentioned effect of Al incorporation on the catalytic activity of Ni catalysts in HDO, notorious differences were observed in the reaction products obtained over the Al-containing NAMx catalysts and the NiMCM one. The product distributions obtained with different catalysts were compared at two levels of anisole conversion: at medium anisole conversion (40%; since maximum anisole conversion reached with the NiMCM catalyst at 6 h time was 38.6%) and at high anisole conversion (96–97%, final conversions obtained with the NAMx catalysts), Table 5. For the reference NiMCM catalyst without aluminum, the main reaction product was cyclohexyl methyl ether (CME) obtained by the hydrogenation of aromatic ring of anisole. The expected deoxygenated cyclohexane (CHA) product was formed only in a small amount (Table 5), being the CME/CHA ratio = 7.39. Modification of the MCM-41 support by the incorporation of aluminum resulted in a radical change in the reaction product composition. For all NAMx catalysts, cyclohexane became the main reaction product at both anisole conversions (Table 5). Other reaction intermediates (CME, cyclohexyl methyl ether; CHL, cyclohexanol; CHE, cyclohexene and BEN, benzene) were formed only in small amounts, being their content slightly higher for the NAM30 catalyst (Table 5). The CME/CHA ratios determined for the NAMx catalysts at 40% of anisole conversion were between 0.05 and 0.46. These results clearly illustrate the effect that Al loading to the MCM-41supports has on the selectivity of the Ni catalysts in HDO of anisole. The NAMx catalysts (x = 120, 90 and 60) demonstrated very high selectivity to CHA (96.3–97.6%) with 100% of selectivity to hydrodeoxygenated products (Table 4), which should be related to the presence of Al atoms in the MCM-41 supports providing acid sites in addition to the metallic Ni nanoparticles. It is well-known that the HDO process of oxygen-containing aromatic molecules has a complex mechanism with several reaction routes including direct deoxygenation, dehydration, hydrogenation, demethylation, and other reactions [44]. Some of these routes can be more or less important depending on the characteristics of the catalyst used. To inquire into the reaction mechanism of anisole HDO over the Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts used in the present work, composition of the reaction mixture was determined at different anisole conversions (Table 5). Cyclohexane is the final fully hydrogenated and deoxygenated product, which can be formed through a series of parallel and consecutive steps including the formation and consumption of different intermediate reaction products. Therefore, to assess the possible reaction mechanism, special attention was placed on the intermediate reaction products. The concentration profiles of these products pass through the maxima, while the concentrations of the final products increase with the reaction time. According to Table 5, at 40% of anisole conversion, in addition to cyclohexane (the main final product), the following products were identified: cyclohexyl methyl ether (CME), cyclohexanol (CHL), benzene (BEN), cyclohexene (CHE), methylcyclopentane (MCP) and dicyclohexyl (DCH). The concentrations of the last three products (CHE, MCP and DCH) were smaller than those of CME, CHL and BEN. The amounts of different detected products slightly changed depending on the catalyst used and the Si/Al ratio in the support. Thus, the NAM90 catalyst is the most selective towards cyclohexane production, while the NAM30 is the least selective. With increasing anisole conversion from 40 to 96–97%, concentrations of CME, CHL and BEN decrease, and at 6 h reaction time CME and CHL are not detected, while BEN can still be detected in a very small concentration. This allows us to consider these three products as intermediates, which are formed from anisole at the beginning of the reaction and then disappear giving rise to cyclohexane. CHE concentration shows similar behavior, but it was discarded as another intermediate product due to a very small concentration. On the contrary, concentration of MCP increases with the reaction time, as well as of other deoxygenated products (M-CHA, methylcyclohexane; and DCH, dicyclohexyl). Therefore, MCP, M-CHA and DCH can be considered as secondary products formed in small amounts (below 2%). Fig. 10 shows how the concentrations of the three intermediate compounds (CME, CHL and BEN) change in the reaction mixture with the reaction time in the HDO of anisole performed with the NAM30 catalyst. It can be noted that all three intermediates appear at the beginning of the reaction and their concentrations decrease similarly. All three intermediates show their maximum concentrations at the same reaction time (0.25 h), which clearly points out to their formation through three parallel reactions. This observation was taken into account to propose the plausible reaction mechanism of anisole hydrodeoxygenation in the presence of Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts ( Scheme 1). This mechanism consists of three parallel reaction routes. In the first one, anisole is converted to phenol through demethylation, and then phenol is hydrogenated to cyclohexanol, which finally suffers dehydration producing cyclohexane. Since phenol (PHE) was not detected in the reaction products, we consider that its transformation to cyclohexanol is very quick. In the second reaction route (Scheme 1), anisole is transformed to cyclohexyl methyl ether, which gives rise to cyclohexane. This reaction route is composed by consecutive reactions of hydrogenation of the aromatic ring in anisole and demethoxylation of cyclohexyl methyl ether. The third reaction route consists of the direct demethoxylation of anisole to benzene via the hydrogenolysis of Caromatic-O bond followed by hydrogenation of benzene to cyclohexane. The possibility of the direct transformation of anisole to benzene was reported previously in the literature [45–47], although the rupture of the Caliphatic-O bond is easier than that of the Caromatic-O bond according to the bond dissociation energies, which are around 80–100 kJ mol−1 higher for Caromatic-O bonds than those for Caliphatic-O bonds [48,49]. On the other hand, the steric constraints of cleaving Caliphatic-O bonds are much higher than for Caromatic-O bonds. The cyclohexene product (CHE) detected in small amounts (< 1%) could be formed according to this mechanism either through dehydration of cyclohexanol (CHL) or through demetoxylation of cyclohexyl methyl ether (CME). Some other secondary reaction products: methylcyclohexane (M-CHA), methylcyclopentane (MCP) and dicyclohexyl (DCH) also detected in small amounts at the end of the reaction (Table 5) could be formed on the acid sites of the Al-MCM-41 supports. 3.4 Effect of Al incorporation on the activity and selectivity of Ni catalysts in HDO of anisole In the present work, anisole hydrodeoxygenation was studied in the presence of bifunctional Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts (NAMx) with different Si/Al ratios (x = 30, 60, 90 and 120). Activity and selectivity results of these catalysts were compared with those obtained with a NiMCM reference without Al. The latter sample represents a monofunctional catalyst with only metallic function and a negligible amount of acid sites (Table 3). Anisole conversions obtained with all NAMx catalysts at 6 h reaction time were of about 96–97%, while the NiMCM catalyst resulted in only 38.6% conversion. Characterization results showed that the presence of Al in the AMx supports and its amount affect characteristics and dispersion of NiO in calcined catalysts and metallic Ni (NiO) nanoparticles in reduced catalysts. Thus, UV–vis DRS and TPR characterization of calcined Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts (Figs. 5 and 6) showed the presence of two types of NiO species: agglomerated ones located on the external surface of the support’s particles and small ones located inside the mesopores of the Al-MCM-41 materials. According to the TPR results, proportion of dispersed NiO species is larger in the catalysts supported on AM120, AM90 and AM60 materials. In line with this, HRTEM characterization of reduced catalysts also showed an increase in the proportion of small metallic Ni nanoparticles (ca. 2 nm) in the above catalysts, especially in the NAM90 (Fig. 7c) with the best catalytic activity (initial reaction rates and rate constants, Table 4). Therefore, the support’s Si/Al molar ratio also affects the dispersion and location of the catalytically active metallic Ni phase. An additional and more notorious effect of Al incorporation in the catalytic supports was detected in the reaction product selectivity. This effect consists in a strong acceleration of the reaction mechanism steps related to C-O bond hydrogenolysis (demethylation, dehydration and demethoxylation) leading to the formation of the final cyclohexane product. These reactions require activation of oxygen atom of the molecule (starting anisole or O-containing intermediate products), which results in a weakening of C-O bonds and their easier hydrogenolysis. According to Hsu et al. [50], this oxygen activation can be reached on an oxophilic promoter (i.e., FeO x , MoO x , and WO x ) added to the metallic Ni catalyst. Such bifunctional catalysts resulted to be effective in the deoxygenation of lignine derivatives (i.e., p-cresol) through direct deoxygenation due to a contact synergy. Alternatively, acid sites can also catalyze the cleavage of C-O bonds [51,52]. Since oxygen atoms have two free electron pairs, they can interact with Lewis or Brønsted acid sites. In the present work, the monofunctional NiMCM catalyst showed a very low selectivity to cyclohexane (CHA) being cyclohexyl methyl ether (CME) the main reaction product (Table 5). This catalyst possesses only reduced Ni nanoparticles as an active phase (Fig. 8), resulting in a good hydrogenation activity. However, the lack of acid sites does not promote the C–O cleavage, preventing the formation of the desired CHA product. On the contrary, NAMx catalysts were highly selective towards formation of fully hydrogenated and deoxygenated product, cyclohexane. This can be attributed to a bifunctional character of these catalysts and to the participation of both types of active sites at different steps of the reaction mechanism (Scheme 1). A similar increase in the selectivity to cyclohexane has been reported recently in hydrodeoxygenation of anisole over Pt/Al-SBA-15, a bifunctional metal-acid catalyst [51]. The introduction of acidity to the SBA-15 support promoted the demethoxylation of the methoxycyclohexane intermediate (called CME in the present work) with an increase in the selectivity to cyclohexane from 15% to 92%. The NAMx catalysts (x = 120, 90 and 60) prepared in the present work showed ever higher selectivity to cyclohexane (96.3–97.6%) along with 100% selectivity to deoxygenated products (Table 4). The best activity and selectivity results were obtained with the NAM90 catalyst with a rate constant k of 1.80 h-1, followed by NAM60, NAM30, and NAM120, and SCHA = 97.6% (Table 4). The NAM90 catalyst had the highest proportion of well-dispersed Ni nanoparticles inside the support’s mesopore channels (Fig. 8c), in addition to the relatively high amount of strong acid sites compared to NAM120 and NAM60 catalysts (Table 3). The presence of two types of reduced Ni nanoparticles in the NAMx catalysts, large particles (10–12 nm) on the external surface of MCM-41 supports and small ones (ca. 2 nm) located inside the mesopores, seems to be important for the catalytic activity and selectivity in HDO of anisole. In our previous work [17], it was observed for the Ni/SBA-15 catalysts prepared by different methods that the catalysts with the larger average Ni particle size (16.2 nm) showed higher activity in hydrogenation of anisole than those with small Ni particles (3.2 nm). Therefore, Ni nanoparticles of different sizes catalyze the hydrogenation of aromatic ring of anisole, but the large metallic Ni particles observed in the catalysts prepared in the present work should be more active. This is the first step of anisole HDO leading to the formation of cyclohexyl methyl ether ( Scheme 2 d). Other hydrogenation steps of the proposed reaction mechanism (Scheme 2 b, g) also take place on the reduced metal nanoparticles. On the other side, demethylation, dehydration and demethoxylation steps of the proposed reaction mechanism require participation of both metallic and acid active sites (Scheme 2 a, c, e, f). For the efficient performance, the Ni species and the acid sites should be proximal one to another, as reported by Song et al. [52]. This can be reached inside the catalyst’s mesopores, where well-dispersed Ni nanoparticles are located near the acid sites provided by the Al-containing MCM-41 support or non-reduced NiO species. Strong acid sites promote C-O bonds activation making easier the cleavage of C-O bonds, while metallic Ni nanoparticles provide dissociated hydrogen for the saturation of the ruptured bonds. Finally, it can be concluded that the excellent catalytic performance of the NAMx catalysts in HDO of anisole is due to a synergistic effect between the metallic Ni active phase and the acid sites of the AMx supports, which enhances the hydrogenation activity and the selectivity of the bifunctional NAMx catalysts to deoxygenated products. Thus, both activity and selectivity of the Ni/(Al)-MCM-41 catalysts passes through the maximum with an increase in the total amount of acid sites ( Fig. 11). It seems that the most active and selective NAM90 catalyst has the optimized metal-acid synergy and an appropriate proportion of large and small Ni nanoparticles. 3.5 Catalyst recycling The most active catalyst (NAM90) was tested in several catalytic cycles of anisole hydrodeoxygenation. After each reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and used again without any additional regeneration treatment. Obtained anisole conversions are shown in Fig. 12. It can be observed that anisole conversions decreased from 96.5% to 90.4% and 80.8% in the second and third catalytic cycles. The above decrease in the catalytic activity of the used NAM90 catalyst could be ascribed to some mass loss of the catalyst upon separation after each reaction cycle, and to deactivation due to coke formation. According to the obtained GCLPA results (Table 4), the formation of 10–20 wt% of coke could be expected in all the catalysts tested in the present work. Therefore, the recycling of the catalysts such as those used in the present study (NAMx) would require some additional regeneration treatment for coke removing [43]. On the other side, no leaching of the active Ni phase into the reaction mixture was detected. 4 Conclusions Al-modified mesoporous MCM-41 materials with different Si/Al ratios (120, 90, 60, and 30) were synthesized and used as supports of Ni catalysts tested in the HDO of anisole at 280 °C and 4.8 MPa of H2 pressure. The supports exhibited the typical pore structure of MCM-41 with a hexagonal array of mesopores. This pore arrangement was maintained in calcined and reduced Ni catalysts. The addition of Al to the MCM-41 support, in general, increases metal-support interaction (MSI) and improves dispersion of NiO and metallic Ni species in comparison with the all-silica MCM-41-supported samples. However, this strong MSI impedes the complete reduction of NiO species upon the used activation conditions (400 oC, 4 h). In addition, too high Al loading in the AMx support (Si/Al molar ratio of 30) produced a decrease of the specific textural characteristics of the AM30 support and an increment in the agglomeration of the deposited Ni species, as corroborated by XRD, TPR, and HRTEM. On the other side, the incorporation of Al in the silica MCM-41 supports generated acid sites of different strengths, leading to the bifunctional metal-acid catalysts. The total amount of acid sites in the NAMx catalysts increases with increasing Al loading in the AMx supports, while the amount of strong acid sites does not follow this tendency. The NAM90 and NAM30 catalysts exhibited larger amounts of strong acid sites than other catalysts. All synthesized NAMx catalysts showed a significantly improved performance in HDO of anisole compared to the Al-free NiMCM analog and the Ni/Al2O3 reference. The presence of acid sites had a beneficial effect on both activity and selectivity of the Ni catalysts. This can be attributed to a bifunctional character of these catalysts combining metal and acid active sites and to a synergistic effect among them. The NAM90 catalyst presented the best activity and selectivity to cyclohexane, fully hydrogenated and deoxygenated product. It seems that this catalyst has the optimized metal-acid synergy. However, when the NAM90 catalyst was tested in three subsequent catalytic cycles, a decrease in the catalytic activity was observed. This deactivation could be ascribed to coke formation, and therefore, coke elimination is needed for repeated catalyst use. Also, a further search for Al-MCM-41-supported catalysts with improved resistance to coke formation is desirable. CRediT authorship contribution statement Luis H. coredata.dc:description: Ni/Al-MCM-41(x) catalysts were synthesized and tested in the hydrodeoxygenation of anisole as a model compound of bio-oil. Prepared catalysts behave as bifunctional metal-acid catalysts combining the metal function of the reduced Ni nanoparticles with the acid function of the Al-MCM-41 supports. Nickel loading in the catalysts was maintained constant (5 wt%), while Al content in the supports was varied (Si/Al molar ratios x = 120, 90, 60 and 30). The Ni/Al-MCM-41(x) catalysts showed significantly higher hydrodeoxygenation activities than the reference Ni/Al2O3 and the Ni/MCM-41 catalyst without Al. In addition, they showed high selectivity towards the formation of the deoxygenated products, with more than 96% selectivity to cyclohexane. The best activity and selectivity results were obtained with the Ni/Al-MCM-41(90) catalyst. This result was attributed to an optimum balance of metal and acid sites, both of which participate in different steps of anisole hydrodeoxygenation and generate a synergistic effect.
coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous Ni/Al-MCM-41 catalysts for highly active and selective hydrodeoxygenation of anisole to cyclohexane
